channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Russia Bombards Kyiv Overnight, but Ukraine Says It Still Holds Capital
item.description: The latest Western intelligence reports indicated that the Russian advance had been slowed, if only temporarily, by intense resistance from Ukrainian troops and civilian volunteers. The Russian priority remained the capture of Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian servicemen at the military airbase of Vasylkiv in the Kyiv region on Sunday.

item.title: Brazil, Land of the Thong, Embraces Its Heavier Self
item.description: A country known for beach bodies is confronting soaring obesity rates with new laws that enshrine protections for people who are overweight.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Dado Galdieri
item.media:description: Mariana Donato, 36, taking a break from her dance classes in Recife, Brazil. She and her dance troupe gathered to rehearse ahead of the Miss Plus Size Fashion pageant in Recife, where they performed routines that challenge thin beauty standards.

item.title: Russia's War With Ukraine Is Already Costing Russian Economy
item.description: Despite the Kremlin’s efforts to obscure the offensive in Ukraine, the costs of the war were already evident in both economic and social turmoil.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Walking past Red Square in Moscow on Saturday.

item.title: Putin’s Aggression Leaves His Right-Wing Fan Club Squirming
item.description: The Russian strongman has for years been idolized by a Who’s Who of populist, nationalist leaders. They are now stumbling over what to say.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Marine Le Pen, the leader of the far-right National Rally party, met President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Moscow in 2017.

item.title: New Amazon Headquarters Sparks Feud Among Indigenous South Africans
item.description: The development, still under construction, sits on sacred land in Cape Town. But some Indigenous leaders have allied with the developers, prompting a debate over who speaks for First Nations people.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: A 37-acre site in Cape Town, on which Amazon is developing its African headquarters, is widely believed to lie in the area where Indigenous South Africans first fought colonial invaders.

item.title: At the Polish Border, Tens of Thousands of Ukrainian Refugees
item.description: They have been warmly welcomed in a country whose border guards last year beat back mostly Afghan and Middle Eastern migrants with batons.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Olha Zapotochna with her gravely ill son, Arthur, after crossing the Ukrainian-Polish border on Friday. “We are still living in the 21st century, I hope,” Ms. Zapotochna said.

item.title: ‘Abrupt Changes’: China Caught in a Bind Over Russia’s Invasion of Ukraine
item.description: China has presented itself as a defender of sovereign independence. But its reluctance to denounce Russia’s aggression forces it into an awkward position.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia meeting with his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, this month in Beijing.

item.title: 8 Found Dead After Ferry Fire Off Greece as Grim Search Continues
item.description: The blaze aboard the Euroferry Olympia burned for most of a week. Hundreds of passengers were rescued, but at least three more are believed missing.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: The Euroferry Olympia near the Greek island of Corfu on Tuesday. Fire broke out aboard on Feb. 18.

item.title: In Video, a Defiant President Zelensky Says, ‘We Are Here’
item.description: The 44-year-old president of Ukraine videotaped himself in Kyiv as Russian forces closed in on the capital, vowing to fight them to the end.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Ukraine Presidency, via AFP/— Getty Imagess
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky early Friday in Kyiv, in a photo provided by Ukraine’s government.

item.title: An Iranian Director’s Rule: ‘Always Focus on Ordinary People’
item.description: Asghar Farhadi, who has won two Oscars, says stories about the rich and famous “are not part of my emotional bank.”
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Rozette Rago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Asghar Farhadi, the Iranian filmmaker, in West Hollywood, Calif., in January.

item.title: Chernobyl Plant Is Unharmed Despite Russian Invasion of Ukraine, Scientists Say
item.description: The nation’s 15 operating reactors have also been assessed as safe — at least for the moment.
item.dc:creator: William J. Broad
item.media:description: The site of the fourth reactor at the Chernobyl nuclear plant in Ukraine in 2017.

item.title: Ukraine War Strains North Africa Economies
item.description: Egypt imports most of its wheat from Russia and Ukraine, and is looking for alternative suppliers. And Tunisia was struggling to pay for grain imports even before the conflict.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Aida Alami
item.media:description: Baking bread in Saqqara, near Giza, Egypt.

item.title: Biden Targets Russia With Strategy of Containment, Updated for a New Era
item.description: President Biden’s plan to counter Russia faces obstacles in an interconnected world. Russia also has a new, if not very enthusiastic, partner in standing up to the West: China.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: President Biden and Russia’s president, Vladimir V. Putin, in Geneva last year. Mr. Biden vowed this week to make Mr. Putin a “pariah on the international stage.”

item.title: South Korea Records Deadliest Day of Pandemic
item.description: A grim milestone is reached a few days after the nation topped 170,000 new cases in a single day.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: People waiting in line at a coronavirus testing site in Seoul on Saturday.

item.title: North Korea Launches a Ballistic Missile, South Korea Says
item.description: Flight data suggested that the missile launched Sunday was less powerful than the last one the North tested, four weeks ago.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Watching news coverage of a North Korean missile launch in Seoul last month.

item.title: Putin’s Critics Call for Boycotts of Russian Vodka
item.description: The governors of New Hampshire and Ohio announced measures aimed halting the sales of Russian-made and Russian-branded spirits.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah
item.category: Virginia Department of Alcoholic Beverage Control
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: The alcohol department at a supermarket in Moscow. In some parts of the United States and other countries, officials are removing Russian vodka from shelves.

item.title: Putin Seems to Sideline Advisers on Ukraine, Taking a Political Risk
item.description: Authoritarian leaders rely on elite support to govern. Jeopardizing those relationships in wartime could be risky, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin leading a Security Council meeting via videoconference in Moscow on Friday.

item.title: Middle East Sympathizes With Ukrainian Refugees
item.description: Many in the region took to social media to express sympathy for Ukrainians forced to flee, though their warm welcome in Europe evoked a tinge of bitterness over the treatment of Arab and Muslim migrants.
item.dc:creator: Mona El-Naggar
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A family from Ukraine arrives in Poland after crossing the border at Medyka on Saturday.

item.title: ‘No City in Ukraine Is Safe’: Family Escapes Missile Strike in Kyiv
item.description: After days in a bomb shelter, a family returned to their home in Kyiv for breakfast, and witnessed a missile strike on a neighboring apartment building.
item.dc:creator: Yousur Al-Hlou, Michael Downey and Masha Froliak
item.media:credit: Michael Downey for the New York Times

item.title: Find the C.D.C.'s New Pandemic Guidance for Your Area
item.description: The guidance is not binding, so local requirements may still apply. The federal mask requirement on mass transit and air travel is set to expire on March 18.
item.dc:creator: Sophie Downes
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: New guidance from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention allows U.S. counties to determine whether to skip masks, social distancing and other pandemic measures. Some localities have already enabled such freedoms.

item.title: Demetrios Papademetriou, Top Immigration Scholar, Dies at 75
item.description: He designed the “Grand Bargain,” an ambitious plan for Mexican immigrants to gain legal status in the U.S., but it collapsed after the terrorist attacks of 9/11.
item.dc:creator: Katharine Q. Seelye
item.media:description: Demetrios Papademetriou at a conference in Paris in 2020. A founder of the Migration Policy Institute, he advised numerous governments about their immigration policies.

item.title: Ukrainian Civilians Arm Themselves to Fight the Russian Army in Kyiv
item.description: Civilian volunteers and paramilitary groups are taking the fight to the Russian army in Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Lynsey Addario
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian volunteers gather and prepare their weapons to fight Russian troops throughout Kyiv on Saturday.

item.title: Putin Faces Sanctions, but His Assets Remain an Enigma
item.description: On paper, the Russian president appears to own very little. Yet estimates put his hidden wealth well over $100 billion.
item.dc:creator: Mike McIntire and Michael Forsythe
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at the G20 summit in Osaka, Japan, in 2019. He is facing sanctions from the United States and its European allies.

item.title: Big tech is betting that offices are still the future.
item.dc:creator: Kellen Browning
item.media:credit: Adam Riding for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Watermark office building at the edge of Tempe Town Lake, Ariz., is home to WeWork, Robinhood and some Amazon employees.

item.title: Russia Advances on 3 Ukrainian Cities, but Meets Fierce Resistance
item.description: Ukraine’s leader said his forces had “repelled” the Russian army’s assault. Moscow claimed it had merely “paused” for the possibility of peace negotiations.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins, Eric Schmitt, Michael Levenson and The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Julia, a teacher and Ukrainian volunteer fighter, wept for her country as she waited to be deployed around Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital, on Saturday.

item.title: Biden and Putin, Children of the Cold War, Face Off Over Ukraine
item.description: Not since John F. Kennedy and Nikita S. Khrushchev confronted each other over Berlin and Cuba have an American president and Russian leader gone eyeball to eyeball in quite such a dramatic fashion.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: Vladimir V. Putin, left, and Joseph R. Biden Jr., right, back to camera, met in Moscow in 2011 when Mr. Putin was prime minister and Mr. Biden was vice president. Both leaders rose to power along distinct paths.

item.title: The C.D.C. releases new masking guidance and Queen Elizabeth tests positive: The week in Covid news.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Brittainy Newman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Exiting Penn Station in New York last week.

item.title: Volodymyr Zelensky Tries to Rally His People as Battle for Kyiv Rages
item.description: “We have withstood and successfully repelled enemy attacks,” President Volodymyr Zelensky said in the video. “The fighting continues in many cities and districts of our state, but we know that we protect the country, the land, the future of children.”
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Ukranian Presidential Press Service via Reuters

item.title: For Ukraine’s Refugees, Europe Opens Doors That Were Shut to Others
item.description: Thousands of Ukrainians will end up in countries led by nationalist governments that have been reluctant to welcome refugees in the past.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Olha Zapotochna and her 3-year-old son, Arthur, after crossing the border from Ukraine into Poland on Friday.

item.title: The Comforts of Nostalgia
item.description: Popular culture is taking us back to the past.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Ukrainian forces slow Russian advance as the U.S. and its allies take action on Russian banks.
With Trucks and Protesters Gone, What's Next For Ottawa?
item.description: Streets remained blocked in Ottawa, and many issues, including compensation for those who lost income during the protests, are unresolved.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Ottawa’s Parliamentary precinct is now separated from the city by steel fences.

item.title: Russia Intensifies Censorship Campaign, Pressuring Tech Giants
item.description: Google, Apple and others were warned that they must comply with a new law, which would make them more vulnerable to the Kremlin’s censorship demands.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano
item.category: Roskomnadzor (Federal Service for Supervision of Communications, Information Technology and Mass Media) (Russia)
item.media:credit: Left and center, Laura Morton for The New York Times; right, Gabby Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: A new Russian law is a move by the Kremlin to counter attempts by tech companies to minimize their physical presence in the country.

item.title: Facial Recognition at Airports: What You Need to Know
item.description: Customs officials aim to save time and increase security by ramping up the use of facial recognition. But what about privacy? A biometrics specialist weighs in.
item.dc:creator: Elaine Glusac
item.media:credit: Ray Whitehouse for The New York Times
item.media:description: Facial recognition screening at Dulles International Airport in Virginia.

item.title: Video Shows Missile Hitting Kyiv Residential Building
item.description: The missile hit a building about 1.5 miles from Sikorsky Memorial Airport.
item.dc:creator: Muyi Xiao, Brenna Smith, Malachy Browne and Sarah Kerr

item.title: On Both Sides of Korean Peninsula, Eyes on Washington's Response to Russia
item.description: North Korea might decide it’s time to resume weapons tests, to gain more diplomatic leverage with Washington.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Watching coverage of the invasion of Ukraine in a Seoul train station on Thursday.

item.title: Russia Ties May Hurt Thousands of European Companies
item.description: European companies that have operations in Russia are preparing for collateral damage as Western sanctions aim to penalize Russia’s economy.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman and Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Moscow’s International Business Centre last year. Many European banks and companies have operations and partnerships in Russia.

item.title: Empire State Building, Eiffel Tower Use Lights to Show Ukraine Support
item.description: The landmarks include the World Trade Center, the Eiffel Tower and more.
item.dc:creator: Nadav Gavrielov
item.media:description: The Empire State Building lit in the colors of the Ukrainian flag on Friday.

item.title: Russia Vetoes UN Security Council Resolution Calling on it to Withdraw from Ukraine
item.description: Eleven countries voted in favor of the U.S.-backed measure, and three abstained.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi

item.title: State Dept. Says Moscow’s Ukraine Diplomacy Was a ‘Pretense’
item.description: Officials in the Biden administration met repeatedly with Russian emissaries as the threat of an invasion of Ukraine grew more apparent.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken met with Russia’s foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, in Geneva in January, one of several meetings between U.S. and Russian officials.

item.title: Canada Approves a Second Vaccine Made Without mRNA Technology
item.description: The clearance given to a plant-based offering developed by Medicago of Quebec City only covers people ages 18 to 64.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: A scientist working in one of Medicago’s laboratories in Quebec City last year.

item.title: Ukraine Girds for Kyiv Attack Amid Signs of Slowing Russian Advance
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky warned in a video address that Russian “sabotage groups” had entered Kyiv with the aim of decapitating his government by “destroying the head of state.”
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins, Andrew E. Kramer and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times

item.title: Russia’s Assault in Ukraine Slows After an Aggressive Start
item.description: The invading forces have faced stiff resistance, but President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia could quickly send in more troops, Pentagon officials said.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A residential building was hit by missiles in southern Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital, on Friday.

item.title: ‘I’m Ready’: Ukraine’s Civilians Take Up Arms
item.description: Volunteer fighters armed with assault rifles patrolled central Kyiv on Friday, ready to defend their country.
item.dc:creator: Yousur Al-Hlou, Michael Downey, Taras Ratushnyy, Mark Boyer and Alexandra Eaton
item.media:credit: Michael Downey for the New York Times

item.title: Maryland Lifts Statewide School Mask Mandate
item.description: The decision gives local school districts the power to decide whether to require face coverings.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:credit: Rosem Morton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zia Hellman, a teacher, helps her student, Averie Colvin, 5, at Walter P. Carter Elementary/Middle School in Baltimore.

item.title: How the U.S. and Europe Are Targeting Putin With Sanctions
item.description: The new penalties are a provocative step given how rarely governments, including the United States, take aim at foreign leaders.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport, Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Katie Rogers
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators at the White House protested on Friday against Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

item.title: Bappi Lahiri, India’s ‘Disco King,’ Dies at 69
item.description: He helped popularize the genre with some of the country’s biggest hits of all time, including “I Am a Disco Dancer.”
item.dc:creator: Alex Traub
item.media:credit: Anshuman Poyrekar/Hindustan Times via Getty Images
item.media:description: Bappi Lahiri in 2011 at his home in Mumbai. He grew up idolizing Elvis for his style and ultimately became known for his own flair — tinted sunglasses, shiny jackets and mounds of gold jewelry.

item.title: Eurovision Bars Russia From This Year’s Song Contest
item.description: “The inclusion of a Russian entry in this year’s contest would bring the competition into disrepute,” the organizers said on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch and Dan Bilefsky
item.media:description: Manizha, the Russian representative in the 2021 Eurovision Song Contest, at the grand finale in Rotterdam, Netherlands.

item.title: A Canadian Leader with Ukrainian Roots Ranks Putin as One of Most ‘Reviled European Dictators.’
item.description: Canada has a large population with Ukrainian roots, including Chrystia Freeland, the deputy prime minister, whose interest in Ukrainian independence dates to the Soviet era.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:description: Canada’s deputy prime minister and minister of finance, Chrystia Freeland, in the House of Commons in Ottawa this month.

item.title: Far-Right Militias in Europe Plan to Confront Russian Forces
item.description: The apparent mobilization of far-right groups could be problematic for the Ukrainian government
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: Members of the Ukrainian Azov Battalion leading military exercises for civilians amid the threat of a Russian invasion, in Kyiv, this month.

item.title: New York City Schools Will Lift Outdoor Mask Mandate
item.description: Masking inside the city’s public schools will still be required, as is the case across the state, but not outside on school grounds.
item.dc:creator: Precious Fondren and Jeffery C. Mays
item.media:credit: Dieu-Nalio Chéry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Starting Monday, New York City public school students and staff members will no longer have to wear masks outdoors on school grounds. An indoor school mask mandate remains in place statewide.

item.title: Russia Will Limit Access to Facebook, A Major Platform for Dissent
item.description: Since President Vladimir V. Putin launched his attack on Ukraine, many Russians have taken to social media to express their anger.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman checked her phone on the Moscow subway in 2020.

item.title: ‘I’ll Stand on the Side of Russia’: Pro-Putin Sentiment Spreads Online
item.description: After marinating in conspiracy theories and Donald J. Trump’s Russia stance, some online discourse about Vladimir Putin has grown more complimentary.
item.dc:creator: Davey Alba and Stuart A. Thompson
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and President Donald J. Trump at a meeting in 2019.

item.title: As Troops Battle Outside Kharkiv, Residents Shelter Underground
item.description: Ukrainian troops dug in around the nation’s second-largest city a day after a fight to push back advancing Russian forces.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz

item.title: Putin Claims Russia Has Been Fighting ‘Nationalist Groups,’ Not The Ukrainian Army
item.description: Russian state television aired brief remarks by Mr. Putin as he spoke by video to his Security Council.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: Russian President Vladimir V. Putin entering a meeting with members of Russia’s Security Council via a video link in Moscow, on Friday.
